awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: NSF: Toward Tracking Organic Carbon Cycling in a Changing Arctic Ocean using Optical Properties and Numerical Modelling
awd_abstract_narration:
Phytoplankton, which form the base of marine food webs, are responding to the associated higher light availability and fresher surface water in the Arctic. Their spring bloom is occurring earlier due to early sea ice melt, and they have recently tended to show a fall bloom. This suggests that the phytoplankton are acclimating to a “new Arctic”. The goal of this project is to improve the understanding of phytoplankton-originating organic carbon cycling through a collaboration with scientists at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) in San Diego, California. The opportunity to collaborate with two leading scientists in the field of optical oceanography at SIO will positively impact and potentially transform the PI’s research career trajectory. These benefits will also enhance the research capacity of the PI’s home institution.

The goal of the project is to 1) investigate phytoplankton changes in response to environmental variables, 2) track vertical export of phytoplankton-originating organic carbon, and 3) predict the impact of phytoplankton changes on zooplankton abundance. The investigator will analyze several comprehensive datasets acquired on five field campaigns to the Arctic between 2010 and the fall of 2021. The data include inherent and apparent optical properties, phytoplankton pigments and community composition, and a full suite of physical and chemical measurements. Samples obtained from the most recent campaign will be shipped to SIO for analysis using a customized optical instrument and technique developed by two leading experts in the field of Optical Oceanography at SIO. The phytoplankton community composition will be derived from the measured phytoplankton absorption spectra. The vertical export of organic carbon will be estimated using an innovative approach based on profiles of particle backscattering. Together with the data from spring and summer campaigns in previous years, the fall data will be used to parameterize a numerical model of the seasonal succession of phytoplankton and zooplankton. The primary outputs will be publications and presentations for both scientific and public audiences. Expected outcomes will consist of training in the state-of-the-art optical measurement and modelling techniques and mentoring of a post-doc in the integration of the knowledge into a numerical model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Phytoplankton living in the Arctic Ocean are vulnerable to environmental changes. How these changes will influence phytoplankton community composition and their seasonality is a critical question for better understanding of the potential impact on the entire marine ecosystem, and yet this is not well documented. In situ data regarding phytoplankton community composition is remarkably lacking. In contrast, a large amount of optical data in Arctic waters has been accumulated over the last two decades. This project examined the relevant link between phytoplankton size distribution, as a first-order measure of community composition, and corresponding bulk optical properties.

The project provided four key outcomes. The first key outcome was the development of a method that allows combining two independent particle and phytoplankton size distributions to be comparable. The second key outcome was a finding of relevant links between phytoplankton size distribution and the bulk absorption coefficient spectrum. The third key outcome was a scheme for deriving intracellular chlorophyll concentration and the imaginary part of refractive index using optical data. These variables vary depending on environmental conditions and thus provide useful insights into the physiological status of phytoplankton living in natural waters. Finally, the fourth key outcome was a reasonable simulation of phytoplankton phenology in Arctic water from sea ice covered to open water periods. These four key outcomes will improve our understanding of phytoplankton community compositions in the past, present, and future though optical and ecosystem modelling.

Knowledge gained from the present project is being applied to monitor for harmful algal blooms (HABs) in Northern New England coastal waters. In recognition of the relevant links between phytoplankton optical properties and HABs, this project allowed us to establish an infrastructure for rapid HABs monitoring at the University of New Hampshire’s Coastal Marine Laboratory (CML/UNH). Along with the determination of phytoplankton absorption spectra that we learned from the leading experts, Dr. Rick Reynolds and Dr. Dariusz Stramski at Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO), we were able to set up an imaging flowcytobot (IFCB, McLANE) at CML/UNH. Since March 11, 2024, we have been monitoring for HABs on a weekly basis. More recently, this monitoring has been acknowledged as an important existing infrastructure in New England and invited to be involved as a part of the National Harmful Algal Bloom Observing Network-Northeast (NHABON-NE) through collaboration with Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) and the Northeastern Regional Association of Coastal Ocean Observing Systems (NERACOOS).

The HAB monitoring activity has involved mentoring of an undergraduate student, two masters students, as well as a research assistant. An undergraduate student generated a phytoplankton morphology library specific to NH waters. This morphology library is being used for identifying phytoplankton taxa including harmful algae and is further used for student mentoring as well. In addition, the present project provided a training opportunity for a post-doc, who expanded his knowledge about ocean optics and remote sensing during our visits at SIO.
